container.heading: Health Requirements for Cattle Passing through Public Stockyards, Public Sales and Livestock Dealers, and Farm to Farm Sales

para.text: "Department" means Maryland Department of Agriculture.
"Secretary" means Secretary of Agriculture or the Secretary’s designee.

All bovine animals are subject to inspection for evidence of infectious disease including those caused by parasites. Affected and exposed animals are not eligible for movement to Maryland farms and shall be consigned directly to slaughter or handled in such a manner as specified by the Secretary.
Diagnostic tests of cattle may be required when it is considered necessary.

Cattle classified as suspects or reactors as a result of a test performed at a stockyard or auction market, shall be consigned directly to slaughter, or handled in such manner as specified by the Secretary, and no indemnity paid. Exposed animals will be handled at the discretion of the Secretary.
It is prohibited for any person or persons to:
Conceal the identity or origin of a bovine animal within the State; or

Remove manually, for the purpose of concealing or falsely representing the identity of the animal, any means of identification such as back tag, ear tag, tattoo, or other means of identification recognized by the Secretary.
Records of Animals Received and Disposed of.

It shall be the duty of each livestock dealer and livestock market operator to maintain a record covering all animals received and disposed of. These records shall include the date of receipt and date of sale, and the name and address of the consignor and purchaser. Each animal shall be identified by a metal ear tag number, tattoo number, purebred name and registry number, or a horn or hoof brand number, by breed, sex, age, and approximate weight, the health status and the purpose for which the animals are consigned, that is, for breeding, feeding, grazing, or milk production. Individual identification is not required for:
Steers, or spayed heifers;
Calves under 8 months old of beef type for feeding and grazing purposes.
These records shall be retained for a period of 3 years.

It shall be the duty of every livestock trucker, livestock dealer, livestock market operator, and slaughtering establishment subject to or maintaining meat inspection, to identify upon receipt, unless already identified by back tag, all bovine breeding animals 2 years old and over originating from herds in this State and received for sale or shipment to a slaughtering establishment.

The identification, unless otherwise authorized by the Secretary, shall consist of an official back tag issued by the Department or the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, U.S.D.A., and shall be affixed to the animals at a point approximately 4 inches behind the shoulder and 4 inches below the top line.

Every person required to identify animals in accordance with this regulation shall file reports, on forms prescribed and at intervals prescribed by the Secretary, of all animals identified including the back tag number and date of application, and the name, address, and county of residence of the person who owned or controlled the herd from which the animals originated.

The requirements of this regulation may not apply to livestock truckers with respect to animals received for delivery directly to a livestock market agreeing to accept responsibility for back tag identification, if at the time of delivery the market is furnished with information identifying the herd of origin.
Animals with one pair of fully erupted permanent incisors will be deemed to be 24 months old.

section.heading: Requirements for Cattle Passing Through Auction Markets or Public Stockyards for Return to Maryland Farms.

para.text: All cattle for return to farms shall be in compliance with Regulation .02A-E.
Brucellosis.
Cattle originating directly from herds not under restriction in Maryland or other certified brucellosis free states may be moved to farms in Maryland without a brucellosis test.
Cattle originating from states not certified brucellosis free shall comply with one of the following:
Be consigned direct to slaughter; or
Be accompanied by an official interstate certificate fully complying with Maryland regulations for importation of cattle from states not certified brucellosis free.
Tuberculosis.
Cattle originating directly from herds not under restriction in Maryland may be moved to farms in Maryland without a tuberculosis test.
Cattle originating from states other than Maryland shall comply with one of the following:
Be consigned direct to slaughter; or
Be accompanied by an official interstate certificate fully complying with the tuberculosis requirements for the importation of cattle into Maryland or meet these requirements before release.
Steers, except those for exhibition purposes and spayed heifers, are exempt from tuberculosis testing requirements.

section.heading: Requirements for Farm to Farm Sales Within Maryland Including Sales from Farms to Dealers to Farms.

para.text: All animals shall be identified in accordance with Regulation .02A—E.
Herd Dispersal Sales.
Brucellosis Requirements. All herds shall comply with one of the following:
Have at least 3 negative milk ring tests within the 12 months immediately preceding the sale;
Have a complete negative brucellosis herd test within the 12 months immediately preceding the sale.
Tuberculosis Requirements. All herds shall have a complete negative tuberculosis test within the 12 months immediately preceding the sale.
Brucellosis and tuberculosis tests are not required for farm to farm sales, or for animals purchased by dealers from Maryland farms and sold to Maryland farms, except as noted in §B, above.
